SCBI_notes: Confirmed presence at SCBI ForestGEO plot starting 2015 (purple traps). Mortality first attributed to EAB in 2016.
general_notes: ID in 2003 (readicated) reconfirmed in 2007 in PA and VA (Fairfax)

SNP_notes: Abies>10cm not present in forest monitoring plots
SCBI_notes: No host trees (Abies sp) in plot
No host trees (Tsuga sp) in plot
Bill McShea reports heavy presense on oaks at SCBI, but not as bad as other locations in the region.
No host trees (Tsuga sp) in plot

SNP_notes: Beech scale and Beech bark disease were both detected in the Park for the first time in October, 2007. Beech mortality was observed in 2014. See spreadsheet: BBD_Detections_at_SHEN.xlsx.
general_notes: Vector for beech bark disease. Puncture holes in bark allow transmission of pathogenic fungi (Nectria coccinea and  Nectria galligena)
Principal vector for Dutch Elm's disease

SNP_notes: Beech scale and Beech bark disease were both detected in the Park for the first time in October, 2007. Beech mortality was observed in 2014. See spreadsheet: BBD_Detections_at_SHEN.xlsx.

Butternut described as common in Berg & Moore 1941; Rolf Gruber, personal communication: Butternut canker has caused mortality in the park. We have seen butternut mortality, and the persisting trees seem to be infected, but I don't think we have done any butternut inventory or monitoring.
SCBI_notes: 8 trees found to be partially defoliated in 2017, no direct evidence of presence

SNP_notes: Mid-1920s introduced in VA, by 1929 had made it through all of S. Appalachia
SCBI_notes: only 1 Castenea in plot over 10cm, healthy as of 2017

native range: unknown (but confirmed exotic; Caetano-Anoll_s et al., 2001)
SCBI_observation_type: observation of symptoms on dead/dying trees
SCBI_notes: death of 79 in 2014, defoliation noted earlier, defoliation and leaf problems noted in 2017

SCBI_observation_type: observation of symptoms on dead/dying trees
SCBI_notes: Confirmed pesent in 2017, presumed present but not recorded since before plot establishment. Ulmus mortality has been high since 2013

SNP_notes: Pine blister rust documented as common problem in 1941 report (Berg & Moore 1941)
SCBI_notes: Symptoms noted since 2016, defoliation, brown needles, sap. No postive ID
cankers and defoliation noted in 2017 on 11 individuals
general_notes: carried by the walnut twig beetle (Pityophthorus juglandis). Was found in June 2011 in Chesterfield, VA and then in 2012 in northern Virginia.

SCBI_observation_type: observation of symptoms on dead/dying trees
SCBI_notes: On unhealthy Cercis trees (~25% in 2017), we have documented various symptoms of this fungus (canker, defoliation, rotten stem, etc).
general_notes: orchard pest. Previously known as Botryosphaeria spp. It is globally distributed, and within the species complex there is unfettered and frequent movement across international borders. (Sakalidis et al. 2013: http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/ddi.12030/full). Known to affect Cercis in the area (refs in Gonzalez-Akre et al.)
carried within the gut of Ips beetles, some species may be invasive, difficult to tell since other species are considered to be cosmopolitan

tree_species_affected: Pinus spp. Abies, Larix, Picea, Pseudotsuga
Many hardwoods (maple, elm, oak, and sucamore; mulberry)

Virginia_source: 2011 Clermont County Ohio, outside Blue Ridge
general_notes: likely not to be an issue in the area in the near future

tree_species_affected: Quercus, Acer, Tilia, Ulmus, and other hardwoods

pest_pathogen_scientific_name: Phellinus robiniae / Phellinus rimosus / Polyporus robiniophilus
SCBI_observation_type: observation of symptoms on dead/dying trees
SCBI_notes: The robinia's most notable common factor is severe and prolonged rot; their trunks actually suffer from so much decay and loss of mass (accompanied by lots of the typical fungi feeding on dead biomass) that it's difficult to distinguish any insect effects on the wood. (observation by Maya P., 2018)

SNP_notes: Wendy Cass reports that she has noticed a lot of locust leaf miner in the park in the last 10+ years (as of 2018)
SCBI_notes: no sign of damage to leaves on declining individuals, which is not consistent with the effects of the locust leaf miner (observation by Maya P., 2018)
general_notes: Outbreaks of the locust leafminer occur practically every year, and thousands of black locusts turn brown and are defoliated. Trees that are defoliated seldom die. However, if the damage occurs during a year of drought, or other poor growing conditions, the trees may be killed. If the trees grow two sets of leaves in one growing season, the combined feeding of larvae and adults may destroy both sets. If this double defoliation occurs several years in a row, the tree may die.

SCBI_notes: no sign of damage to leaves on declining individuals, which is not consistent with the effects of locust borer (observation by Maya P., 2018)
general_notes: Locust borer larvae construct feeding tunnels throughout the wood, and the holes serve as entry points for heart rot fungi that cause extensive wood decay.

SCBI_observation_type: detected in Malaise trap 2015 or earlier; mortality attribution to 4 trees in 2016 (Meakem) and two in 2017 (Helcoski)

tree_species_affected: Fraxinus, Tilia, Fagus, and other hardwoods
Acer, Populus, Quercus, and other hardwoods
Acer saccharum, Acer rubrum, Betula spp.
Hardwoods (esp. Betula spp. and Juglans nigra)
Ulmus, Quercus, Acer, Fagus, Fraxinus and other hardwoods

pest_pathogen_scientific_name: Phellinus igniarus, Phellinus laevigatus, and Phellinus tremulae
tree_species_affected: Hardwoods (esp. aspen, beech, birch and maple)

native range: S US; SCBI&SHEN are near the edge of native range (probably outside), more at risk under climate change
SNP_notes: Southern pine beetle caused fairly significant mortality to pitch, Virginia, and table mt. pines in the park's South District in the early 90s. Wendy Cass reports that she remembers it being pretty dramatic in sections of the south district with whole stands decimated when we re-sampled them in the late 1990's.
general_notes: SPB is native to the southeastern United States but has been expanding its range up the Eastern Seaboard in recent years. Warming of extreme winter temperatures has most likely contributed to this expansion. Last major outbreak in VA was in the early 1990s
damage is mostly aesthetic and generally does not  affect  the  overall  health  of  the  tree

pest_pathogen_common_name: Walnut anthracnose or walnut black spot
SNP_notes: mentioned as common on butternut in Berg & Moore 1941
